meta.content: A small angle x-ray scattering simulator has been developed for metrology and inspection applications based on the first Born approximation considering non-ideal equipment-related factors. The simulator shows good reproducibility in various device structures and measurement environments, including slit-configurations and incident angles. In addition, a Q-space adaptive weighting method is proposed to enhance about 300% accuracy, especially on non-single repeated pitch structures such as VNAND with complex x-ray diffraction patterns.
meta.name: citation_abstract

div.div: A small angle x-ray scattering simulator has been developed for metrology and inspection applications based on the first Born approximation considering non-ideal equipment-related factors. The simulator shows good reproducibility in various device structures and measurement environments, including slit-configurations and incident angles. In addition, a Q-space adaptive weighting method is proposed to enhance about 300% accuracy, especially on non-single repeated pitch structures such as VNAND with complex x-ray diffraction patterns.

Advanced semiconductor devices require the incorporation of sophisticated 3D structures, such as FinFET, GAA, and VNAND, some of which have high-aspect-ratio (HAR) features.
1,2
1. B. Doyle
et al.
, “
Tri-Gate fully-depleted CMOS transistors: Fabrication, design and layout
,” in
Symposium on VLSl Technology Digest of Technical Papers
(
IEEE
, 2003), pp. 133–
134
.
2. J. Jang
et al.
, “
Vertical cell array using TCAT (Terabit Cell Array Transistor) technology for ultra high density NAND flash memory
,” in
Symposium on VLSl Technology Digest of Technical Papers
(
IEEE
, 2009), pp. 192–
193
.
Optical Critical Dimension (OCD) or CD-SEM (scanning electron microscopy) have served as main non-destructive structural monitoring metrologies for those structures; however, they also have shown insufficient optical sensitivity to the various 3D features with a HAR unless using lower wavelengths such as deep ultraviolet (235–160 nm).
3
3. R. Silver
et al.
, “
Fundamental limits of optical critical dimension metrology: A simulation study
,” Proc. SPIE
6518
, 65180U (2007).
https://doi.org/10.1117/12.716604
In addition, much smaller dimensional confinement and more complex architectures induce the difficulties with changes in the material dielectric function as well as parameter cross-correlations.
4
4. C. Settens
et al.
, “
Critical dimension small angle X-ray scattering measurements of FinFET and 3D memory structures
,” Proc. SPIE
8681
, 86810L (2013).
https://doi.org/10.1117/12.2012019

Critical dimension small angle x-ray scattering (CD-SAXS), with a wavelength less than 0.1 nm, has been developed by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST).
5
5. B. Bunday
et al.
, “
Gaps analysis for CD metrology beyond the 22 nm node
,” Proc. SPIE
8681
, 86813B (2013).
https://doi.org/10.1117/12.2012472
CD-SAXS is a supportive candidate for the next in-line metrology solution because it is non-destructive, needs no sample preparation, and can conform to 50–100
μ
m scatterometry targets. CD-SAXS has started to be partially used together with the conventional metrology despite its low throughput.
6,7
6. M. Wormington
et al.
, “
X-ray critical dimension metrology solution for high aspect ratio semiconductor structures
,” Proc. SPIE
11611
, 116110W (2021).
https://doi.org/10.1117/12.2583966
7. M. Korde
et al.
, “
X-ray metrology of nanowire/nanosheet FETs for advanced technology nodes
,” Proc. SPIE
11325
, 113250W (2020).
https://doi.org/10.1117/12.2553371

The overall view of the CD measurement used in this paper is described here. At first, the reference data are acquired by destructive measurements for emphasis on measurement accuracy. A typical measurement method of structures is scanning electron microscopy (SEM) or transmission electron microscopy (TEM). For repeated HAR structures such as VNAND channel holes, it is also possible to acquire data to several thousand samples at the same time by a combination of sloped etch. After that, a process model is created so that the target structure is reproduced with a process simulator such as Synopsys Sentaurus Topography. Virtual structures are created by the Monte Carlo method, and an optical simulation is executed with the structure. It helps to reduce the number of measured samples, while it is not possible to completely eliminate actual measurements. The process simulator generates more realistic structural features than those created by randomly changing geometric parameters of an analytical structure model. These simulations make it possible to boost the number of reference data to over 10 000 points. At last, a model for CD extraction is created by machine learning (ML) with database (DB) of the structure data and optical data. The newly coming measurement data, for example, in the case of inline, are referred to the modeled DB to identify the target structure quickly.

We have investigated SAXS to predict 3D device’s structures, with the base of the first Born approximation
8
8. B. Max, “
Quantenmechanik der stoßvorgänge
,” Z. Phys.
38
, 803–
827
(1926).
https://doi.org/10.1007/BF01397184
considering non-ideal equipment-related factors. The simulator reproduces reference scattering patterns of different structures precisely, and the proposed weighting filter on 2D Q-space improves the CD extraction accuracy very well to support advanced 3D structure manufacturing.

The first Born approximation is used for x-ray scattering simulation because potential strength for secondary scattering on different atoms is as very small as 10
−8
.
9
9. S. Blügel,
Scattering Theory: Born Series
, Lecture Notes of the 43rd IFF Spring School (
Forschungszentrum, Jülich
, 2012), ISBN:
978-3-89336-759-7
.
Thus, the easy-to-interpret kinematic interpretation with only primary scattering is sufficient to describe the x-ray scattering. The intensity of scattered x rays [
Is
(
q
)] is
I
s
q
=
∫

r
,
(1)
where ρ(
r
) is the scattering length density on x rays. An interface to topography simulation is implemented on a SAXS simulator to prepare the measuring target device structure as shown in
Fig. 1
. Material profiles are extracted with a process simulator, and ρ(
r
) is calculated through them.

FIG. 1.
Experimental setup of SAXS and basic theory. The transmission of x rays is detected, and first Born approximation on x rays is applied for scattering simulation. The future Metrology and Inspection (MI) computing aided platform is based on real-time and non-destructive optical metrology (OCD + SAXS) for the target device fabricated with topography simulation.

The scattering pattern on far away fields, which is detected by a detector, is calculated with fast Fourier transfer (FFT). The dependence on the angle of incidence (AOI) is determined with FFT after rotating coordinates (
r
→
r

with rotation matrix [
Rot
(AOI)]. The experiments use a sub-nm wavelength (0.050 nm) x-ray beam that penetrates through the backplane of a Si substrate, which forms only the zeroth order scattering peak, meaning near the center, and can easily be separated from the diffractions caused on the target device.

Figure 2
shows scattering patterns of a device structure with different incident angles (AOI = 0°, 1°, and 2°). Strong peaks appear due to interference of periodical features of the device. To evaluate scattering patterns, the goodness of fit (GOF or ξ) is defined
10
10. A. F. Hannon
et al.
, “
Advancing x-ray scattering metrology using inverse genetic algorithms
,” J. Micro/Nanolithogr., MEMS, MOEMS
15
(3), 034001 (2016).
https://doi.org/10.1117/1.jmm.15.3.034001
as
ξ

1

1

)
.
(2)

FIG. 2.
Reference and simulation data. Diffraction intensity on Q-space (q
x
, q
y
) on SAXS with a single repeated pitch (SRP) honeycomb structure is shown in the upper figure, with different incident angles (AOI = 0°, 1°, and 2°). In the bottom figures, blue and red lines show intensity (q
x
= 0, q
y
) and intensity (q
x
, q
y
= 0) of the reference and light-blue and pink lines show intensity (q
x
= 0, q
y
) and intensity (q
x
, q
y
= 0) of the simulation.

FIG. 3.
Goodness of Fit (GOF) calculated with peak heights. 0.50 nm-margin is needed for the uniqueness because the GOF has a little distribution (<0.03) even when comparing simulation and reference with the same structure, such as the radius in the range of 8–40 nm.

Figure 4
shows other scattering patterns with a VNAND-like structure having through-holes and word line cut space. The complicated peak patterns, which are light-blue and pink line on left, are shown in
Fig. 4
. This is because of interference of two different repeated pitches. These complicated peak patterns make it difficult to estimate the GOF from diffraction intensities with peak locations
q
n
{@peak}.

FIG. 4.
Reference and simulation data for the non-single repeated pitch (NSRP) structure. In the left figure, the blue and red lines show intensity (q
x
= 0, q
y
) and intensity (q
x
, q
y
= 0) of the reference and the light-blue and pink lines show intensity (q
x
= 0, q
y
) and intensity (q
x
, q
y
= 0) of the simulation. The NSRP structure has two different feature pitches on a cell. The diffraction intensity on Q-space (q
x
, q
y
) has complex scattering peak patterns on simulation compared with that on
Fig. 2
.

The smearing effect is one of the non-ideal equipment-related factors, and it needs to be considered in SAXS simulation.
11
11. J. Bergenholtz
et al.
, “
Analysis of small-angle X-ray scattering data in the presence of significant instrumental smearing
,” J. Appl. Crystallogr.
49
, 47–
54
(2016).
https://doi.org/10.1107/s1600576715023444
The origin of smearing is finite collimation and detector resolution as shown in the left of
Fig. 5
. Assuming a smearing function
W
k
=
exp
−
k
2
/
2
σ
2
,
(3)
the intensity of x-ray scattering [
Im
(
q
)] on the detector is calculated by
I
m
q
=
∫
W
(
k
)
×
I
s
q
−
k
d
k
.
(4)

FIG. 5.
Smearing effect evaluation. Smearing is caused by the finite collimation and detector resolution on the measurement system. The right figure shows the evaluation result of the effect on different slit sizes (0.2–2.0 mm).

As shown in the right of
Fig. 5
, small slits of experimental components decrease the distribution (σ) of
W
(
k
) and suppress the smear effect for diffraction pattern sharpness. In an optimized measurement setup, the sample distance is 5.5 m, the beam size is 200
μ
m, and the S/N ratio is 140 dB against the maximum peak on the detector. The throughput in this measurement setup is several tens to hundreds of minutes per unit of the product, while it is about an order of magnitude lower than that of OCD that is the de facto standard measurement on semiconductor inspection systems, especially for 3D structures. This is one of the bottlenecks for introducing the SAXS system as an in-line measuring on Fab.

The signal intensity related to measurement throughput also depends on the slit configuration and location of the target as well as the detector and decreases with the increase in pattern sharpness. Ignoring the smear effect is difficult, and it is desired to develop a stable x-ray light source with higher intensity to eliminate the trade-off.
Figure 6
shows the diffraction intensity pattern on the same non-single repeated pitch (NSRP) structure as shown in
Fig. 4
, considering smearing with the evaluated distribution parameter (σ = 0.012 nm
−1
). It is found that the diffraction patterns are well reproduced in a wide range of Q-space.

FIG. 6.
Reference and simulation results. The diffraction intensity pattern on the non-single repeated pitch (NSRP) structure, as shown in
Fig. 4
, considers smearing with the distribution parameter (
σ
= 0.012 nm
−1
). In bottom figures, the blue and red lines show intensity (q
x
= 0, q
y
) and intensity (q
x
, q
y
= 0) of the reference and the light-blue and pink lines show intensity (q
x
= 0, q
y
) and intensity (q
x
, q
y
= 0) of the simulation.

The model that connects the structural features and the optical data is created in ML. The principle of the maximum likelihood method works when processing in ML. The model search proceeds under the condition that the uncertainty is implicitly minimized. The number of measurement data is several thousands to tens of thousands, while there is no need to set up an analytical model and compare it to the uncertainty of the model and measurements.
12,13
12. D. F. Sunday
et al.
, “
Determining the shape and periodicity of nanostructures using small‐angle X‐ray scattering
,” J. Appl. Crystallogr.
48
(5), 1355–
1363
(2015).
https://doi.org/10.1107/s1600576715013369
13. D. F. Sunday
et al.
, “
Evaluation of the effect of data quality on the profile uncertainty of critical dimension small angle x-ray scattering
,” J. Micro/Nanolithogr., MEMS, MOEMS
15
(1), 014001 (2016).
https://doi.org/10.1117/1.jmm.15.1.014001
Under ML-based modeling, it would be guessed that the accuracy of the CD can be improved by increasing condensation of the information.

A new GOF calculation method, here, is introduced because the GOF calculated in a full range of Q-space has a problem of comparison at a low-signal level under noise. The weighting filter is extracted upon comparing two scattering patterns with different sigma (σ). Smearing function
W
(
k
), modeled with the Gaussian function as shown in Eq.
(3)
, has the following relation to sigma:
δ
W
W
=
k
2
σ
2
⋅
δ
σ
σ
.
(5)

δ
W
/
W
is calculated to be 0.4 when k = 2
σ
and
δ
σ
/
σ
= 0.1 utilizing the above relation. Therefore, the filter, having signals to pass with δ
Im
/
Im
lower than 0.4, limits the GOF calculation region, which is important for signal intensity within 95% inclusion (
Fig. 7
). The filtering regions are dependent on the target device structure and adaptively modified to the optimal shape in this method.

FIG. 7.
Adaptive weighting filter method. The adaptive weighting filter is produced by the calculated ideal diffraction pattern and the Q-space limitation around the center of each interference peak. The limitation area is derived by that 95% signal is included in the range k < |2
σ
| according to Eq.
(5)
.

As shown in
Table I
, the new method has maximum ×3 accuracy to identify the Critical Dimension (CD) due to the averaging effect on the limited region, including the high S/N ratio. GOFs calculated on only peak locations or full-range Q-space have the degradation as the index in the case of NSRP (structure in
Fig. 4
) or NSP (structure in
Fig. 2
), respectively. It is found that the proposed adaptive weighting filter effectively screens the signal from noise on Q-space and suppresses the degradation of the GOF as index for CD extraction.

TABLE I.
Summary of GOF calculation methods. The proposed GOF is calculated with the adaptive weighting filter as shown in
Fig. 7
. (*1) The structure shown in
Fig. 2
and (*2) the structure in
Fig. 3
. (*3) q
n
is only on peaks for calculating GOF (*4) q
n
is in all Q-space (−0.2 nm
−1
< q < 0.2 nm
−1
).

The GOF applying the logarithm of the intensities induces good results because
(1)
the boundary of the filtering region is extracted by the Gaussian distribution function and
(2)
the smearing effect is large in the target region. Several data-analysis methods have been proposed so far.
14,15
14. V. Soltwisch
et al.
, “
Reconstructing detailed line profiles of lamellar gratings from GISAXS patterns with a Maxwell solver
,” J. Appl. Crystallogr.
50
, 1524–
1532
(2017).
https://doi.org/10.1107/s1600576717012742
15. M.-A. Henn
et al.
, “
Improved reconstruction of critical dimensions in extreme ultraviolet scatterometry by modeling systematic errors
,” Meas. Sci. Technol.
25
, 044003 (2014).
https://doi.org/10.1088/0957-0233/25/4/044003
When compared with these methods, considering that it follows the principle of maximum likelihood with the base on Gaussian distribution, the extraction of the model with our proposed method on ML is the same. On the other hand, the difference is on constraint for modeling. The Gaussian function is used to define a region with a large signal strength, but it is not necessarily modeled to follow the Gaussian distribution with the region. Investigation into how this difference affects the modeling with ML for SAXS data is a future work.

In conclusion, the developed SAXS simulator shows good reproducibility under various conditions. The weighting evaluation filter on Q-space is effective in both cases with single and non-single repeated patterns and enhances the quality of the GOF to induce about 300% CD accuracy improvement to characterize the 3D structure with HAR, such as VNAND.
DATA AVAILABILITY
The data that support the findings of this study are available from the corresponding author upon reasonable request.
